docs.lead_paragraph: Lead oil industry negotiator Royal Dutch Shell Plc, said negotiations with the United Steelworkers union (USW) toward a new three-year national contract covering hourly workers at 63 U.S. refineries that account for 64 percent of national refining capacity were continuing.

docs.lead_paragraph: A congressionally appointed panel on U.S. military compensation recommended overhauling retirement and healthcare benefits on Thursday to improve services offered to troops and families while cutting costs by up to $12.6 billion annually.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Bulgarian doctor Irena Marinova arrived in an ambulance at the home of a pregnant Roma woman in November, she says she was beaten up by two men who accused her of being late.

headline.print_headline: Ambulance Attacks Open Wound of Roma Relations in Bulgaria

docs.lead_paragraph: The study found evidence of “adverse tiering,” or placing all of the drugs used to treat H.I.V. in a specialty tier, where consumers are required to pay at least 30 percent of the cost of the drug.

headline.main: Study Finds H.I.V. Drugs Priced Out of Reach
headline.print_headline: Study Finds H.I.V. Drugs Priced Out of Reach

docs.abstract: Harvard researchers publish study in The New England Journal of Medicine that shows that quarter of plans on new health care exchanges may be putting HIV and AIDS drugs in tier that requires patients to pay at least 30 percent of drug's cost; practice makes drugs too expensive for many patients, and is illegal under health care reform law.
docs.snippet: The study found evidence of “adverse tiering,” or placing all of the drugs used to treat H.I.V. in a specialty tier, where consumers are required to pay at least 30 percent of the cost of the drug.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicaid has become less uniform and more complicated, with variations across states, but researchers will be able to watch many experiments bloom.

headline.main: The Goal Was Simplicity; Instead, There’s a Many-Headed Medicaid
headline.print_headline: How the New Health Law Failed to Simplify Medicaid

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Pres Obama's Affordable Care Act was designed to simplify Medicaid and make it easier for poor to receive medical care, but law allows states to offer more variations of the program than ever before; though complicated and confusing, researchers can now study variations by regions to see which policies may work.
docs.snippet: Medicaid has become less uniform and more complicated, with variations across states, but researchers will be able to watch many experiments bloom.
